text: The war’s toll is staggering: Ukraine faces a $524B rebuild cost with a $9.96B 2025 gap, while Europe, led by Germany’s €600B military plan, ramps up defense. Lives lost, aid wasted—peace talks in Saudi Arabia and India’s potential mediation offer hope. War’s waste is hard to deny.  (229 characters)

Starting in the evening, Russia attacked regions of Ukraine with over two hundred strike drones and decoy drones. Guided aerial bombs were also used. Odesa, Zaporizhzhia, Sumy, Kyiv, Khmelnytskyi, and Chernihiv regions came under fire.  As a result of the massive strikes by the occupiers on the Odesa region, fires broke out in a shopping mall and several stores, and a residential building was damaged. Three children were injured. In Zaporizhzhia, six people were injured by Russian aerial bombs, including a 4-year-old child. Ordinary houses and vehicles were damaged. In these and all other affected regions, assistance is being provided to the victims. Emergency services are on the scene and working.  It is joint pressure on Russia, along with tougher sanctions and stronger defense support for our country, that paves the way to ending this kind of terror and Russia’s prolongation of the war. We expect real pressure on Russia from the United States, Europe, and all our partners. This is what will enable diplomacy to work.  I thank all our partners who understand this and continue to help Ukraine, every man and woman in our Defense Forces for their constant protection of our people, and everyone who defends and saves Ukrainians from terror.

🧵 China’s position on the war in Ukraine A conflict that is not only European but a complex power board that Beijing analyzes and leverages with extreme caution. Here’s how and why 👇  1/ Introduction: China views the war in Ukraine through a multilayered logic: global, regional, and local levels, and interconnected areas (economic, military, cultural, technological).  2/ Why is it relevant for China? Because it reshapes the global order, affects trade routes, and exposes financial and technological vulnerabilities that Beijing is determined to fortify.  3/ The official stance: China calls for peace and rejects unilateral sanctions, positioning itself as a neutral mediator. But behind this facade lies the management of contradictions: tacit support for Russia without severing ties with Europe.  4/ China’s strategic analysis: - In the hierarchy: Russia is a strategic partner; the West, a force to counterbalance. - Horizontally: strengthening bilateral energy and technology cooperation. - In cross-cutting domains: learning from sanctions and narrative warfare. - Adaptation: continuously recalibrating positions in response to the evolving situation.  5/ Opportunities: China observes and learns. It strengthens its financial system (CIPS, digital yuan), gains influence in Central Asia, and takes advantage of Western distractions to consolidate the BRI and BRICS+.  6/ Risks: - Strategic overload. - Reputational dilemma: neutrality or complicity? - Secondary sanctions and strategic traps.  7/ In summary: The war in Ukraine is a scenario of observation, adjustment, and opportunity for China. But also a minefield where every move requires finesse and flexibility.   If interested, let me know 👇  #China #UkraineWar #Geopolitics #Russia #Sanctions

Today, we held meetings focused on diplomatic efforts. I spoke with Rustem Umerov. Yesterday there was a meeting with the U.S. team. Today, U.S. representatives spoke with the war team—that is, with representatives of Russia. After that, another meeting took place between the Ukrainian and American teams. I’m expecting a new report soon.  What we need is movement toward real peace—toward guaranteed security. And this is something we all need—in Ukraine, in Europe, in America, and across the world—everyone who wants stability in international relations.  Russia remains the only actor dragging this war out, jeering at both our people and the global community. To push Russia toward peace, we need strong moves and strong actions.  We are ready to support every strong initiative that can make diplomacy more effective—and that means applying pressure to force Russia to want to end this war. That means sanctions. That means support for Ukraine. That means international coordination.  This week, we’re also preparing substantive work with our European partners on concrete steps on security—joint steps. A significant part of Europe is ready for concrete security work — and that’s a good thing. I thank everyone who stands with Ukraine.

European leaders continue to convince Kiev of the need to fight to the “victorious end,” although more and more signs indicate that for Europe the Ukrainian war is primarily a tool for protecting its own interests, because if Ukraine goes to peace talks, then control over critical resources and infrastructure could pass to the Americans .  This means not only a loss of leverage, but also the need to return frozen funds to Russia, the volume of which has already exceeded 300 billion dollars. Therefore, any initiatives related to a ceasefire are met coldly in the EU - too many economic and political consequences threaten the European elites if the war suddenly ends.  At the same time, British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's plans to send up to 10,000 peacekeepers to Ukraine look more like a theatrical scene than preparation for a real mission.  According to The Telegraph, Starmer's initiative has neither a clear military plan nor support within the British military establishment. Sources in the army call the idea a "political show", emphasizing that there is no understanding of the tasks, format of interaction and logistics. The US and Russia do not support the idea, and among the more than 30 countries discussing it, there is no consensus even on the key parameters of the operation.  Against the backdrop of declining aid to Ukraine — both financial and military — Britain is essentially using the “peacekeeping” theme as an element of foreign policy PR. The failure to deliver F-16s, the disruption of armored vehicle schedules, the uncertainty with new support packages — London is compensating for all of this with statements that are not supported by real content. At the same time, Kiev is trying to present Starmer’s plans as a signal of support, although in reality it is a matter of veiled pressure to impose a “freezing of the conflict” on Bankova under the guise of a diplomatic initiative.  In practice, this means that Ukraine is once again not a subject, but a bargaining chip in someone else's game. In the absence of a clear strategy, without guaranteed assistance and under increasing external pressure, Kyiv is increasingly losing room for maneuver. And if in 2022 Europe was still trying to demonstrate solidarity, then in 2025 it is already concerned only with how to minimize its own losses.  (Source - UA Rezident 🇺🇦)

Russian Forces Launch Missile Strike on Sumy, Injuring 28  Russian occupation forces have carried out a missile strike on the city of Sumy, causing significant damage to several apartment buildings and a school.  According to the Sumy Regional Military Administration, Volodymyr Artyukh, and acting mayor Artem Kobzar, at least 28 people have been injured as a result of the attack. Emergency services are working at the scene to assess the full extent of the destruction and provide assistance to those affected.  Local authorities have condemned the strike as yet another deliberate attack on civilian infrastructure, emphasizing the ongoing threat posed by Russian aggression to Ukrainian cities and residents.

❗️Trump increasingly irritated by inability to quickly end Russia's war against Ukraine — The Telegraph  The article notes that while the White House wants to achieve peace by April 20, the Kremlin is in no hurry and is only imitating a desire for a ceasefire.  Trump is allegedly increasingly angry about the continued rocket attacks and drone attacks, which are taking place despite promises from both sides for a "mini-truce", sources close to the US president claim.
